docs.title: Backup
docs.description: Starting a backup

docs.title: Log file (.journal)
docs.description: A continuously-used database is always record changes, additions or deletions. Performing regular backups of data is important but does not allow (in case of incident) restoring data entered since the last backup. To respond to this need, 4D now offers a specific tool: the log file. This file allows ensuring permanent security of database data.

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: 4D includes a full database backup and restore module.

docs.title: Restore
docs.description: 4D allows you to restore entire sets of database data in case of any incidents, regardless of the cause of the incident. Two primary categories of incidents can occur:

docs.title: Backup Settings
docs.description: Backup settings are defined through three pages in the Database Settings dialog box. You can set:

docs.title: About the 4D Language
docs.description: The 4D built-in language, consisting of more than 1300 commands, makes 4D a powerful development tool for database applications on desktop computers. You can use the 4D language for many different tasksâ€”from performing simple calculations to creating complex custom user interfaces. For example, you can:

docs.title: Arrays
docs.description: An array is an ordered series of variables of the same type. Each variable is called an element of the array. An array is given its size when it is created; you can then resize it as many times as needed by adding, inserting, or deleting elements, or by resizing the array using the same command used to create it. Array elements are numbered from 1 to N, where N is the size of the array. An array always has a special element zero. Arrays are 4D variables. Like any variable, an array has a scope and follows the rules of the 4D language, though with some unique differences.

docs.title: BLOB
docs.description: - A BLOB (Binary Large OBjects) field, variable or expression is a contiguous series of bytes which can be treated as one whole object or whose bytes can be addressed individually. A BLOB can be empty (null length) or contain up to 2147483647 bytes (2 GB).

docs.title: Boolean
docs.description: A boolean field, variable or expression can be either TRUE or FALSE.

docs.title: Branching structures
docs.description: If...Else...End if

docs.title: Collection
docs.description: Collections are ordered lists of values of similar or mixed types (text, number, object, boolean, collection, or null).

docs.title: Components
docs.description: A 4D component is a set of 4D methods and forms representing one or more functionalities that can be installed in different databases. For example, you can develop a 4D e-mail component that manages every aspect of sending, receiving and storing e-mails in 4D databases.

docs.title: Control flow overview
docs.description: Regardless of the simplicity or complexity of a method, you will always use one or more of three types of programming structures. Programming structures control the flow of execution, whether and in what order statements are executed within a method. There are three types of structures:

docs.title: Data types overview
docs.description: In 4D, data are handled according to their type in two places: database fields and the 4D language.

docs.title: Date
docs.description: - A Date field, variable or expression can be in the range of 1/1/100 to 12/31/32,767.

docs.title: Error handling
docs.description: Error handling is the process of anticipating and responding to errors that might occur in your application. 4D provides a comprehensive support for catching and reporting errors at runtime, as well as for investigating their conditions.

docs.title: Identifiers
docs.description: This section describes the conventions and rules for naming various elements in the 4D language (variables, tables, objects, forms, etc.).

docs.title: Interpreted and Compiled modes
docs.description: 4D applications can work in interpreted or compiled mode:

docs.title: Looping structures
docs.description: While...End while

docs.title: Methods
docs.description: A method is basically a piece of code that executes one or several actions. In the 4D Language, there are two categories of methods:

docs.title: Null and Undefined
docs.description: Null

docs.title: Number (Real, Longint, Integer)
docs.description: Number is a generic term that stands for:

docs.title: Objects
docs.description: Variables, fields or expressions of the Object type can contain various types of data. The structure of "native" 4D objects is based on the classic principle of "property/value" pairs. The syntax of these objects is based on JSON notation:

docs.title: Parameters
docs.description: Using parameters

docs.title: Picture
docs.description: A Picture field, variable or expression can be any Windows or Macintosh picture. In general, this includes any picture that can be put on the pasteboard or read from the disk using 4D commands such as READ PICTURE FILE.

docs.title: Plug-ins
docs.description: As you develop a 4D application, you will discover many capabilities that you did not notice when you started. You can even augment the standard version of 4D by adding plug-ins to your 4D development environment.

docs.title: Pointer
docs.description: A Pointer variable or expression is a reference to another variable (including arrays and array elements), table, field, or object. There is no field of type Pointer.

docs.title: A Quick Tour
docs.description: Using the 4D language, printing the traditional "Hello, world!" message on screen can be done in several ways. The most simple is probably to write the following single line in a project method:

docs.title: Shared objects and collections
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: String
docs.description: String is a generic term that stands for:

docs.title: Time
docs.description: - A Time field, variable or expression can be in the range of 0000 to 596,00000.

docs.title: Variables
docs.description: Data in 4D is stored in two fundamentally different ways. Fields store data permanently on disk; variables store data temporarily in memory.

docs.title: Variant
docs.description: Variant is a variable type which allows encapsulating data of any valid regular type in a variable. Typically, this variable type can be used to write generic code returning or receiving values for which the type is not known. This is the case for example for code handling object attributes.

docs.title: Object libraries
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Pictures
docs.description: Native Formats Supported

docs.title: Style sheets
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Button Grid
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Button
docs.description: A button is an active object that can be assigned an action (e.g., a database task or an interface function) to perform when a user clicks on it.

docs.title: Check Box
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Combo Box
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Drop-down List
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: About 4D Form Objects
docs.description: You build and customize your application forms by manipulating the objects on them. You can add objects, reposition objects, set object properties, enforce business rules by specifying data entry constraints, or write object methods that run automatically when the object is used.

docs.title: Group Box
docs.description: A group box is a static object that allows you to visually assemble multiple form objects:

docs.description: Overview

docs.title: List Box
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Hierarchical List
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Picture Button
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Picture Pop-up Menu
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Plug-in Area
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Progress Indicator
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: JSON property list
docs.description: You will find in this page a comprehensive list of all object properties sorted through their JSON name. Click on a property name to access its detailed description.

docs.title: Radio Button
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Ruler
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Shapes
docs.description: Shapes are static objects that can be added to 4D forms.

docs.title: Spinner
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Splitter
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Static picture
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Stepper
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Subform
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Tab Controls
docs.description: A tab control creates an object that lets the user choose among a set of virtual screens that are enclosed by the tab control object. Each screen is accessed by clicking its tab.

docs.title: Text
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: 4D View Pro area
docs.description: 4D View Pro allows you to insert and display a spreadsheet area in your 4D forms. A spreadsheet is an application containing a grid of cells into which you can enter information, execute calculations, or display pictures.

docs.title: Web Area
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: 4D Write Pro area
docs.description: 4D Write Pro offers 4D users an advanced word-processing tool, fully integrated with your 4D database. Using 4D Write Pro, you can write pre-formatted emails and/or letters containing images, a scanned signature, formatted text and placeholders for dynamic variables. You can also create invoices or reports dynamically, including formatted text and images.

docs.title: Installation and activation
docs.description: Welcome to 4D! You will find below all necessary information about how to install and register your 4D application.

docs.title: Menu bar features
docs.description: Menu bars provide the major interface for custom applications. For each custom application, you must create at least one menu bar with at least one menu. By default, Menu Bar #1 is the menu bar displayed in the Application environment. You can change which menu bar is displayed using the SET MENU BAR command.

docs.title: Creating menus and menu bars
docs.description: You can create menus and menu bars:

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: You can create menu bars and menus for your 4D databases and custom applications. Because pull-down menus are a standard feature of any desktop application, their addition will make your databases easier to use and will make them feel familiar to users.

docs.title: Menu item properties
docs.description: You can set various properties for menu items such as action, font style, separator lines, keyboard shortcuts or icons.

docs.title: SDI mode on Windows
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Activity analysis Page
docs.description: The Activity analysis page allows viewing the contents of the current log file. This function is useful for parsing the use of a database or detecting the operation(s) that caused errors or malfunctions. In the case of a database in client-server mode, it allows verifying operations performed by each client machine.

docs.title: Backup Page
docs.description: You can use the Backup page to view some backup parameters of the database and to launch a manual backup:

docs.title: Compact Page
docs.description: You use this page to access the data file compacting functions.

docs.title: Encrypt Page
docs.description: You can use this page to encrypt or decrypt (i.e. remove encryption from) the data file, according to the Encryptable attribute status defined for each table in the database. For detailed information about data encryption in 4D, please refer to the "Encrypting data" section.

docs.title: Information Page
docs.description: The Information page provides information about the 4D and system environments, as well as the database and application files. Each page can be displayed using tab controls at the top of the window.

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: The Maintenance and Security Center (MSC) window contains all the tools needed for verification, analysis, maintenance, backup, compacting, and encrypting of data files. The MSC window is available in all 4D applications: 4D single user, 4D Server or 4D Desktop.

docs.title: Repair Page
docs.description: This page is used to repair the data file when it has been damaged. Generally, you will only use these functions under the supervision of 4D technical teams, when anomalies have been detected while opening the application or following a verification.

docs.title: Restore Page
docs.description: Restoring a backup

docs.title: Rollback Page
docs.description: You use the Rollback page to access the rollback function among the operations carried out on the data file. It resembles an undo function applied over several levels. It is particularly useful when a record has been deleted by mistake in a database.

docs.title: Verify Page
docs.description: You use this page to verify data integrity. The verification can be carried out on records and/or indexes.

docs.title: Architecture of a 4D project
docs.description: A 4D project is made of several folders and files, stored within a single parent database folder (package folder). For example:

docs.title: Building a project package
docs.description: 4D Developer includes a final application builder to create a project package (final build). This builder simplifies the finalization and deployment process for 4D compiled applications. It automatically handles the specific features of different operating systems and facilitates the deployment of client-server applications.

docs.title: Creating a 4D project
docs.description: Requirements

docs.title: Developing a project
docs.description: Development tools

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: A 4D project contains all of the source code of a 4D database application, from the database structure to the user interface, including forms, menus, user settings, or any required resources. A 4D project is primarily made of text-based files.

docs.title: {dataClass}
docs.description: Dataclass names can be used directly in the REST requests to work with entities, entity selections, or methods of the dataclass.

docs.title: $asArray
docs.description: Returns the result of a query in an array (i.e. a collection) instead of a JSON object.

docs.title: $atomic/$atonce
docs.description: Allows the actions in the REST request to be in a transaction. If there are no errors, the transaction is validated. Otherwise, the transaction is cancelled.

docs.title: $attributes
docs.description: Allows selecting the related attribute(s) to get from the dataclass (e.g., Company(1)?$attributes=employees.lastname or Employee?$attributes=employer.name).

docs.title: Users and sessions
docs.description: Authenticating users

docs.title: $binary
docs.description: Pass "true" to save the BLOB as a document (must also pass $expand=)

docs.title: $catalog
docs.description: The catalog describes all the dataclasses and attributes available in the datastore.

docs.title: $compute
docs.description: Calculate on specific attributes (e.g., Employee/salary/?$compute=sum) or in the case of an Object attribute (e.g., Employee/objectAtt.property1/?$compute=sum)

docs.title: Server Configuration
docs.description: Using standard HTTP requests, the 4D REST Server allows external applications to access the data of your database directly, i.e. to retrieve information about the dataclasses in your project, manipulate data, log into your web application, and much more.

docs.title: $directory
docs.description: The directory handles user access through REST requests.

docs.title: $distinct
docs.description: Returns the distinct values for a specific attribute in a collection (e.g., Company/name?$filter="name=a*"&$distinct=true)

docs.title: $entityset
docs.description: After creating an entity set by using $method=entityset, you can then use it subsequently.

docs.title: $expand
docs.description: Expands an image stored in an Image attribute (e.g., Employee(1)/photo?$imageformat=best&$expand=photo)

docs.title: $filter
docs.description: Allows to query the data in a dataclass or method (e.g., $filter="firstName!='' AND salary>30000")

docs.title: Getting Server Information
docs.description: You can get several information from the REST server:

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.description: 4D provides you with a powerful REST server, that allows direct access to data stored in your 4D databases.

docs.title: $imageformat
docs.description: Defines which image format to use for retrieving images (e.g., $imageformat=png)

docs.title: $info
docs.description: Returns information about the entity sets currently stored in 4D Server's cache as well as user sessions

docs.title: Manipulating Data
docs.description: All exposed datastore classes, attributes and methods can be accessed through REST. Dataclass, attribute, and method names are case-sensitive; however, the data for queries is not.

docs.title: $method
docs.description: This parameter allows you to define the operation to execute with the returned entity or entity selection.

docs.title: $orderby
docs.description: Sorts the data returned by the attribute and sorting order defined (e.g., $orderby="lastName desc, salary asc")

docs.title: $querypath
docs.description: Returns the query as it was executed by 4D Server (e.g., $querypath=true)

docs.title: $queryplan
docs.description: Returns the query as it was passed to 4D Server (e.g., $queryplan=true)

docs.title: About REST Requests
docs.description: The following structures are supported for REST requests:

docs.title: $savedfilter
docs.description: Saves the filter defined by $filter when creating an entity set (e.g., $savedfilter="")

docs.title: $savedorderby
docs.description: Saves the order by defined by $orderby when creating an entity set (e.g., $savedorderby="")

docs.title: $skip
docs.description: Starts the entity defined by this number in the collection (e.g., $skip=10)

docs.title: $timeout
docs.description: Defines the number of seconds to save an entity set in 4D Server's cache (e.g., $timeout=1800)

docs.title: $top/$limit
docs.description: Limits the number of entities to return (e.g., $top=50)

docs.title: $upload
docs.description: Returns an ID of the file uploaded to the server

docs.title: $version
docs.description: Image version number

docs.title: Managing 4D users and groups
docs.description: Designer and Administrator

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: If more than one person uses a database, which is usually the case in client-server architecture or Web interfaces, you need to control access or provide different features according to the connected users. It is also essential to provide security for sensitive data. You can provide this security by assigning passwords to users and creating access groups that have different levels of access to information in the database or to database operations.
